content.description:
This is a newer route that is not in the Orton guidebook. 

  Climb up through underclings and smeary feet to a balancy crux around the third bolt.  After a small bulge, the route moves up and left, following a vast slab for another 100+ feet.  The slab features much easier climbing than the start but offers plenty of opportunities to blow it.  When the angle kicks back even more, belay from a pair of old bolts (these are also the top anchors for Apache Acid) or scramble about 30 feet higher and belay from a pair of glue-ins.  It took almost all of a 70m rope to reach the glue-ins, so I'm not sure whether you could go that far on a 60m. 

  A new intermediate anchor has been added, providing the option of climbing the steeper bottom section and skipping about half of the slab.
content.protection: 18 bolts to reach the highest anchor (two glue-ins).  Two lower anchors are also available.
content.location:
Start left of Acne Problem below a wall of downward-facing flakes. 

  To descend, walk off by scrambling up and right until you reach the trail near the summit of Flagstone.

content.description: Climb the common start of Acne Problem, at the first bolt look left and take the second of the two bolt lines veering up and left. Fun slab climbing with great protection.
content.location: Find Hydrotube and take second bolt line to the left on the corner.

content.description:
Start out at the base of the Hydrotube.  I generally lead up and clip the first bolt of the tube, then veer right (I don't think it adds much rope drag).  Some say that a #3 Camalot protects a supposed run-out section to the 2nd bolt, but I'd venture to say that it is not that run out, and gear is a waste of time.  Fun slab climbing on good edges and underclings.   

  A short bouldery crux is thought provoking during the last 3 (very closely spaced) bolts. 

  One 60m rope works fine if you lower off from the first anchors. 

  There is a 2nd pitch that climbs a right facing corner but I haven't climbed it.  If you plan on climbing the 2nd pitch bring a small selection of gear to 2". 

  Walk off, or rappel with 2 ropes.
content.location: Start at the base of the Hydrotube.  Rappel from the first set of anchors w/ one rope or continue up the 2nd pitch w/ two ropes to rappel, or walk off.

content.description:
Hydrotube would be a classic climb anywhere and is one of the most unique climbs you'll find in Oregon.  

  Pitch 1: (5.8+)  Begin up the middle of the obvious tube on well placed bolts.  The crux comes midway up this first pitch with a few friction moves and edges and quickly eases off as the angle decreases.  Belay at ledge to the left of the tube on beefy anchors. 

  Pitch 2:  Step right from the anchors and climb up a few dicey moves until it eases off considerably.  Continue straight up another steep section (15ft) and scramble to the summit. 

  Walk off down trail to the right or rappel with two ropes.
content.protection:
Take many draws as the first pitch is long.  All anchors are well bolted.  

  A 60m will barely make it down from the first pitch anchors.

content.description:
Climb up into a shallow dihedral, then turn the arête next to it and continue up into another shallow dihedral.  After exiting the second dihedral to the right, the crux pulls a small bulge on edges and sidepulls.  After this, continue up easier slabby terrain to a two-bolt anchor.   

  The three-dimensional terrain of dihedrals and arêtes makes for some interesting moves on this route.
content.protection: Bolts (about 9) with a two-bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
Start two bolt lines to the right of Hydrotube, just left of a shallow dihedral. 

  Rappel with two 60m ropes or one 70m rope.

content.description: Climb the common start of Acne Problem, at first bolt look left and take first of two bolt lines beneath a set of visible chains. Climb up and slight left up a slab to a thin section just as the wall steepens (crux). Pitch two is 5.8 slab up to the chains. Two rope rappel, or walk off.

P1 Crux right off the ground then cruise up low angled rock to belay ledge.  

  P2 Step out right and move up past 2 more bolts to top. (same P2 as hydro tube)
content.protection: Bolts. The route can also be led all on natural gear, include aliens and hb offsets as well as a .75 camalot.
content.location: 2nd bolted line to the left of Hydrotube.

content.description: This face is west facing and is cool in the morning but can get warm on summer days.  This is most popular area of the crag due to its concentration of high quality moderates and the superclassic Hydrotube 5.8
